pass_1_identification.step: Scan within the image for separately defined/delimited decision-making elements, flowcharts, or logical pathway structures.
Look for visual indicators of decision trees such as: diamond-shaped decision nodes, rectangular process boxes, arrows indicating flow, branching pathways, and conditional logic.
Identify potential entry points (starting conditions) and endpoints (outcomes or final steps).
Mark all potential decision tree areas and keep your findings in your mind.
Look for text that suggests decision-making processes such as: "if", "then", "else", "choose", "decide", "assess", "evaluate", conditional questions, and branching scenarios.
Note any visual elements that suggest logical flow: arrows, connecting lines, branching structures, sequential numbering, and hierarchical organization.

decision_tree_criteria.criterion: Contains clear decision points with conditional branching (if/then logic)
Has logical pathways connecting different elements
Demonstrates decision-making process rather than just information display
Shows multiple possible outcomes based on different conditions
Contains at least one decision node and one outcome/process node
Has clear directional flow indicated by arrows, lines, or logical sequence

pathway_verification.step: Verify that pathways connect logically from decision points to outcomes or next steps.
Confirm that branching occurs based on conditions, responses, or criteria.
Check for "choose your own adventure" elements where multiple valid paths exist.
Identify any loop-back structures or recursive decision points.
Verify that all pathways lead to logical conclusions or further decision points.

context_check.step: Analyze text immediately before and after the potential decision tree to understand context and purpose. Don't return that text, just keep it in your mind.
Verify the structure represents decision-making rather than just organizational relationships or static information.
Reject if the structure is merely a hierarchical organization chart, network diagram, or informational display.
Confirm the presence of conditional logic and decision-making elements.
Reject if part of a larger text section, reference list, or non-decision making diagram.

complexity_assessment.step: Evaluate whether the decision tree represents simple binary choices or complex multi-path scenarios.
Identify probabilistic elements if present (probability values, likelihood assessments).
Note cross-references to external figures, procedures, or additional decision trees.
Assess whether multiple valid endpoints exist for different scenarios.
Document any user-dependent or context-dependent pathway variations.

full_decision_tree_capture.step: If a decision tree is verified, capture all nodes, pathways, and logical connections according to the format provided within the XML tags.
Map complete pathways from entry points to all possible endpoints.
Document all conditional branching and the criteria that determine pathway selection.
Capture any loop-back structures or recursive elements.
Include cross-references to external figures, tables, or procedures.
Analyze and document the overall decision-making logic and "choose your own adventure" elements.
Ensure all nodes are properly categorized as decision, process, outcome, or reference nodes.
